AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2
Original Release: 2013
Genre Tags: FPS; Stealth; Sniper; Linear
My Overall Grade: B+
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 5-10 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: Auxiliary
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Game atmosphere connoisseurs
REVIEWSniper: Ghost Warrior 2 is a narrow-pathed, story-driven FPS with minor stealth elements.  The campaign is highly story driven and will escort you from scene to scene as you progress; don‚Äôt expect an open world, or much freedom to explore in the main game.  (The DLC expansion, however, does provide a more open-world experience).  There is also a multiplayer mode which did have a small number of active players at the time I played this.

What I found most enjoyable about Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2 was the main campaign.  I really enjoyed the simple storyline, the pacing of the game, and the landscapes which you explore.  The graphics may not be the absolute best, but I really found the levels to be attractive and interesting.  The story wasn‚Äôt earth-shatteringly good but it kept me interested throughout my playthrough.  The story guides you through narrow-pathed levels as events unfold.  Don‚Äôt expect to be able to do much exploration or anything; although, there are some hidden collectibles to search for (even then: scarcely off the main path).

You are a sniper, so most of the gameplay revolves around moving (stealthily) from one sniper spot to the next, picking off enemies as effectively as possible.  There are stance, breathing, gravity, and wind mechanics that are taken into consideration when you snipe.  And you are supposed to snipe‚Ä¶ you won‚Äôt be able to Rambo" through the game

reviewText:
An ‚Äúok‚Äù non-AAA game that provides a mainstream stealth and sniping experience.

Presentation and writing are mediocre and clich√©d, but I was already expecting this. Otherwise, the story is not bad, and slightly more down-to-earth than most Call of Duty games of late. Levels are very linear and heavily scripted. You are guided by your spotter who stays at your side most of the time. This provides good immersion and manages to convey the sense of working as a team, but his AI is a bit unreliable when in open combat.

The scripting is fairly basic and lacks some polish. There were various issues, like dialogue getting cut off, or checkpoints not reloading correctly. A few times my character would confirm over radio that I had the target in my crosshair, but the target was no where to be seen on my screen. The checkpoint save system has the usual irritations associated with such a system. It is also a pity the difficulty settings offer no more options beyond ‚Äúeasy, medium, hard‚Äù - I wanted to play ‚Äúmedium‚Äù, but without the ‚Äúred dot‚Äù aim assist that ruins the sniping challenge. Also, once you have started, there is no option to change the difficulty later. I had a few crashes to desktop. All these issues were very annoying, but did not ruin the experience.

The graphics are decent (as you would expect from the CryEngine) but do not quite have the same visual quality as the Crysis games. Some areas look really nice, but others less so. The standard quality setting are poorly optimised. I achieved much better fps after careful tweaking (tip: put ‚Äúobject detail‚Äù on low for massive fps boost and next to no quality loss).

Controls are ok, but feel a bit clunky and are unresponsive in some contexts. Fortunately there is no mouse lag or acceleration. Weapon handling and ballistics are ok, but not simulator grade. The game lacks a detailed tutorial and you cannot ‚Äúzero‚Äù the sights to various ranges like you can in ARMA and Red Orchestra 2. The simulation of wind on bullets feels artificial because the wind speed is not effectively reflected in the environment - vegetation does not respond accordingly and there are no other indicators like the sound of wind or moving dust etc. The displayed distances seem to be fake - an ingame distance of 400m is actually closer to 200m (a sin many mainstream games commit one way or another to be more accessible to console peasants). Compared to Far Cry 3, this game was clearly made on a smaller budget, with less content, freedom and polish, but in the end I still liked the single player campaign more here. It is more cohesive and serious, while Far Cry 3 was a theme park of absurd sensationalist violence.

Overall this is a decent second-rate game I mildly enjoyed. I had very modest expectations, and it satisfied them. Get it when on sale.

reviewText: Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2 is a superior shooter when compared to its predecessor. Granted, that isn't saying much.City Interactive has addressed virtually all of the sore points that made the earlier game miss as often as it hit. This is an accomplished stealthy shooter, with smarter enemy AI, more-realistic sniper physics, and scaled-down difficulty that provide a challenging, not maddening, sniping experience. Only miscues like the spread-out save checkpoints and throwaway multiplayer keep it from achieving greatness.Most of your time with Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2 will be spent with the three-part campaign. You play as Cole, a special-ops sniper helping out assault teams in hot zones ranging from the Philippines to Sarajevo to Nepal.A well-written, well-acted script give the game a great action-movie vibe, as do authentic-looking visuals and animations powered by the CryEngine 3. Excellent sound effects do a wonderful job of pulling you in. Weapon noises, the shouts of enemy voices, the far-off rattle of weapon fire and various atmospheric sounds like the background are all handled extremely well and enhance the tension as you line up each careful shot.Shooting is also much more enjoyable, whether you're using a mouse-and-keyboard setup or a gamepad. In the earlier game, bullet drops were extreme, slight winds significantly affected shots, and your heart rate caused the scope to carom all over the place. Here, the physics here are just right.Gameplay is now more focused on stealth than shooting. All of the pure action episodes of the last game have been ditched for a more intense sniping approach where you stay hidden as much as possible, only popping out for quick headshots and silent knife kills. That said, there are some shortcomings. The biggest is the checkpoint system, which saves your progress too infrequently.  The joys of stealth are also occasionally dampened by level linearity.Also you occasionally need to play through particularly tricky parts of levels once or twice before learning enemy patrol patterns which is sometimes frustrating.Multiplayer is pretty much an afterthought. All you get is team deathmatch and a pair of maps. Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2's story and stealth make for a satisfying and entertaining single-player campaign. The frustratingly few-and-far-between checkpoints and MIA multiplayer are disappointments, but this is a worthy sniping experience, especially given the game's budget price. Overall 7/10.

reviewText:
Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2 is a first person shooter that focuses on stealth and sniping and presents itself with quite a couple of improvements over the 2011-released prequel.

The story is stereotypical modern first person shooter bla bla. Terrorists try to obtain a weapon of mass destruction and you have to stop them before they get the chance to use it... so, really exciting stuff there. While the story is as generic as it can be, the storytelling and the dialogues, combined with the actual gameplay, work out surprisingly well and keep things going without every really boring you to death.

S:GW2 is based on the CryEngine 3 (the same engine used for Crysis 3) and while the original game already looked fairly decent, S:GW2 made an even bigger step forward towards visual quality. The texture detail, lighting and level design of the different locations made me stand still and just look around for a bit more than once.

Along with the enhanced visuals, the gameplay mechanics also greatly improved. The AI in the prequel was a horrible pain as enemies would spot you through walls or over a distance of hundreds of meters. Thankfully, the AI was completely re-done for S:GW2, so enemies behave like they should and also show some actual intelligence as, depending on the area, they will try to flank you from all sides or hide behind cover. Additionally, if you break the line of sight or hide in foliage, they will start searching for you.

Each of the 'hotspot' areas in the levels provide you with one or more overwatch spots from which you can safely identify your targets and take them out either one by one, 2 with one bullet if they stand in line or even an entire group if you shoot a grenade on one of the enemy's belts. Alternatively, you can also get closer and take them out either with your knife or your silenced sidearm and if you want to be a real Ghost, you just sneak past them so they will never know you were there.

As the enviroments change, you will have to utilize your thermal or night vision to progress safely and spot your enemies. While this is a nice gimmick and the night vision is often required in really dark areas, I barely used the thermal vision, though it can help spot enemies that blend into the enviroment or are covered by obstacles. The visions are also pretty much the only gadgets you have and while you get C4 charges during certain key points in the game, it feels somewhat lame to not be able to place Claymore mines and lure enemies into them. Or just blow them up with frag grenades.

While the prequel had some action-heavy levels where you actually went head-on towards your enemies and mowed them down with your combat rifles, S:GW2 doesn't feature something like that at all. You have to stick with your sniper rifle as your primary weapon at all times and while the game actually is called 'Sniper', I feel like this strict sniper rifle-only thing killed a bit of the gameplay dynamic and possible replayability of the game as it eliminates the option for the player to replay a level and, instead of silently sniping the enemies, just going nuts with an assault rifle and pumping bullets into everything that moves.

I tried to be as stealthy as possible, so the base campaign took me around 6.5 hours to beat. The Siberian Strike DLC, which consists of 3 fairly lengthy levels, added another 2.5 hours on top of it. While a couple people seem to be still playing the multiplayer mode, I can't comment on that as I was never able to join a server and gave up after dozens of tries and a couple attempts to fix it.

All in all, S:GW2 is a huge improvement over the sequel and seeing what turds City Interactive has produced in the past (prior to S:GW), it's good to see that they can do something decent for a change. If they keep up this level of quality, I might eventually start looking forward to their upcoming games again.

If you're looking for a decent and good-looking sniper experience, make sure to give S:GW 2 a shot (A shot - get it? Because it's a sniper game... hahahaha. Ah, nevermind).

reviewText:
My thoughts on Sniper - Ghost Warrior 2:

Singleplayer:

A linear action-shooting game (duh), where most of the time you either crouch behind bushes/cars/walls/trees, trying to get the perfect shot on an enemy, or walk from one hideout to the next. For someone like me who likes a good Sniper shot from miles away, waiting several seconds up to a minute just for one good shot is okay, everyone else can stop reading here and leave.
The game is called Sniper for a reason - because that is what makes 85% of the game. The rest is either running or the occasional kill with a gun or knife.
The story is average, nothing big to be expected, but enough to keep the game interesting. I liked the parts where you had to fight your way along a (linear) path, and the game does a good job of giving you the feeling that you're a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing sniper and every shot has to be a killing one. There are some challenging parts but you never feel like there is no way you can make it further unless you really suck at using a sniper rifle or feel the need to blast everything away, because you can't.


Multiplayer:

Avoid like ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing hell. You'll feel like there is a huge ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• blinking sign above your head while your opponents don't even have a visual model.


The game comes with an impressively good soundtrack and nice graphics. If using sniper rifles is what you enjoy most in other shooters this game may be yours, but if you're looking for a fast-paced action game like CoD or CS you're wrong here.

Can recommend the basic game, especially when on sale, but not the expansions and the multiplayer mode.

reviewText:
Sniper Ghost Warrior 2 is a stealth action game with focus, as the name of the game hints, on sniper rifles. Single player story offers about 5 hours of entertainment, which actually felt long enough - If the game had more playtime with current features, it would get repetitive.

In 10 levels you can expect a lot of linear gameplay, with exceptions like parts where you can choose if you want to go through with stealth or shoot everybody (and somehow survive). But expect most parts being based on stealth, as your only weapons are sniper rifle, silenced pistol and knife - all the time.

This action game is one of the most newbie-friendly action games I've seen lately. Even on normal difficulty the game felt easy, it's hinting you every 100 meters where you should move next. And most of the time you will be on action with your partner (invincible NPC who doesn't do much damage) who will be signalling exactly what you should do - shoot this bad guy, move there, beware of the spotlight etc.

I was actually surprised that for a lower priced action game, Sniper Ghost Warrior 2 felt good and had a great atmosphere, made thanks to surprisingly good visuals and well done voice acting. Even the story, though it's not something complex, was interesting and made the game into something more than just another corridor shooter with optional stealth.

Sniper Ghost Warrior 2, unlike the previous part, deserves full recommendation if you don't mind the linear gameplay and shorter length. Even those looking for multiplayer might have get some fun there, as I've seen few active deathmatch servers with players. So, what are you waiting for? Take your sniper rifle and go to war!


For more reviews, join Samurai Vader's Point of View group and follow my curator page, I'm always happy to see feedback about my reviews.

reviewText:
Coming into this game from Sniper Ghost Warrior 1, I wasn't expecting much. I gave that a negative review even though I tried very hard to like it, but comparing this game to its predecessor blew my mind.

Let's start listing some things. I'll be combining Pros with Cons since some things offset each other.
+The graphics are BEAUTIFUL. This game running on Cryengine puts its predecessor on the Chrome engine in the dust.
+The story in this is slow to start going, but once you get into it you just want to keep going. It's very immersive and intriguing and I wish it was longer.
-The point of 'longer' is true. I beat this game's campaign in 4 hours. Hardly enough time to enjoy everything the game had to offer.
+But what else did it have to offer? Well the general gameplay mechanics are much better. The mission flow is much smoother. There are much less gameplay bugs to be found in this game. It makes it predecessor look half-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• in comparison.
-However, the game does suffer from a severe lack of optimizations. For one, the V-Sync does not work. For two, the game suffered so many graphical glitches on DX9 that it was rendered unplayable. DX-11 ran correctly, but not as smoothly. With my beast of a rig I was only able to mantain an average of 50 fps (Meanwhile I can run games like Arma 3 with well over 120 fps). Lastly, I experienced one CTD while playing the second mission of the first act. Not sure if its a common thing or a one-off, but I feel obliged to mention it.
- The multiplayer is eh. It's just two teams staring at each other across the map, taking shots at each other, while one guy on each team is running around rambo as if this is call of duty, and at least one person is smack-talking every other person in the match. It doesn't do much to extend the life of the game. A co-op mode would have really helped this game.

Overall this game blows its predecessor out of the water. I'll give this an 8/10 for what it is. If it was properly optimized, if the story was a bit longer, or if the multiplayer was really worth playing, it may have earned a higher score. This is still twice the rating I gave to its predecessor, and so I would definitely recommend picking this title up whenever you get the chance.

reviewText:
Ok so there is a lot wrong with this game, but also a lot that's good. Here is a pro-con list:

Pros:
-Graphics are beautiful
-The gameplay is definitely unique. It takes patience and planning, but manages to be smooth no matter how many mistakes you make
-This is probably the only shooter I have ever played that forces you to rely on an A.I. as a teammate, while actually programming it to never get in your way or get you killed.

Cons:
-The voice acting and story-line are BEYOND bad. It's almost as if the devs were trying to make it as cheesy and un-original as possible. Kind of like Bood Dragon, except it's not meant to be a joke.
-Campaign is extremely short.
-The player has NO freedom of choice. You won't find a game more linear than this one unless you play a side-scroller. Most of the time it feels as though the game is playing itself, and you're just there to click the mouse button a few times. Even when you are left without your spotter, you are still told who to shoot and when by a voice in your helmet.
-The multiplayer is a joke. Don't even bother.

Conclusion: This game was worth the $4.50 I spent on it while it was on sale, but I wouldn't pay a penny more. The campaign will keep you entertained for about 4 hours until you beat it. After that, just uninstall. It's not worth the hard drive space.

reviewText:
3 years after the somewhat mediocre first episode, City Interactive completed its job on the sequel. Was it for the better or for the worse? Well, let's see it!

---Graphics: This certainly is an improvement! The game looks stunning with the CryEngine. I still think the first episode's graphics were decent but City definitely made a good choice by licensing the 3rd iteration of the CryEngine. Water effects and the jungles / lush forests look simply stunning.

---Campaign: Unfortunately, no changes here. The story is still very, very shallow; sections are quite repetitive and the campaign is overall very short. SMG / rifle sequences are now completely eliminated - this is now good as they were very irritating and made the game very difficult. Finally, emphasis is really on the titular sniper shooting and nothing else! There is now an urban (Sarajevo) and mountain (Tibet) area to make the story more interesting. This is all good but as mentioned the new campaign is also very short. Also, you can easily see how heavily the story mode is scripted: you can only go where the designers intended for you to do so.

---Multiplayer: Very few levels available for you to practice sniping on. Also, I am not a camper so lying on the ground for extremely long minutes to see something happen is not my cup of tea. It is overall very slow-paced; once you have found the best hiding - / vantage points on the levels available there is nothing else to see.

I still do not know where to put Ghost Warrior. The 2nd episode is better but still a very short, mediocre experience for gamers out there regardless of their affection towards sniping. Good sniping can be found in the Sniper Elite franchise which does offer much, much more.

reviewText:
Heyyo, it's a pretty decent game tbh. It's not a AAA Game like Sniper Elite series (The WWII sniper game by Rebellion) but it definitely holds its own. :)

The sniping? Well, since this is a sniper game? I guess that should be discussed first heh. The game takes into account bullet drop, wind direction, stance, elevation and stamina (how many beats per minute your heart is doing) so the mechanics are all there ok. The bullet cam is very much like Sniper Elite, but no model damage on the enemies. They just flop over. There's also the hold shift to slow down time and make it feel more movie-like and make it easier to hit moving targets. If you sit in sniper/scope mode long enough? The game gives you a little red circle to show where the bullet will hit and highlight when ontop of an enemy... so as a sniper game? It's good... but Sniper Elite feels more rewarding when you land a shot since you see what kind of damage you're doing.

It has a decent enough storyline... Quite generic tbh but it was good enough for me to want to finish the game.

The voice acting is also nothing flattering but works good enough to make me want to finish the game.

The Gameplay? Eh, after playing Sniper Elite and Sniper Elite V2? Gameplay isn't as good as those games. There's no disguises and trying to sneak around... the campaign is extremely scripted where you spend most of it doing exactly what your spotter tells you to do or you die.. speaking of which? Once enemies start hunting for you? The AI will definitely 360 no-scope you at close range. Super annoying when I try to ambush them and as soon as they rush through a doorway? Bullets hit me before their character turns around and I'm dead... so that's seriously annoying lol.

The graphics? They're pretty darn good, definitely not the best on Cryengine but I'd say a step above State of Decay (another good game built on Cryengine).

The music? Eh, I think there's only three or four songs for the complete game as most maps feature the same songs... They're ok I guess.

Sound effects? Well? Since most of the game you're only using about three different guns (silenced pistol, silenced sniper rifle and a long range silenced sniper rifle) for the whole game? There isn't that much variety in sound effects. The sounds that are there are pretty good though.

My Steam account says I beat the campaign in 5.2 hours and the asking price is $21.99 CAD... so that equates to $4.22 per hour. I don't plan on playing multiplayer since I'm not much of a multiplayer FPS guy these days I guess. So do I feel like it was worth $4.22 an hour? Kinda I guess. It was fun enough... but there's some older games with a longer campaign for the same asking price that'll give you more entertainment. I'd say get the first Sniper Elite game and see what you think of that game before buying this one tbh. Maybe the same with the first Sniper: Ghost Warrior game.. but of course I don't own that so I can't directly give my opinon on that game, but this one is ok so I'm guessing the first Sniper: Ghost Warrior is also ok.

reviewText:
I advise not expecting too much from this game.
(The following review is only about the single player campaign.)

As its name suggest, Sniper Ghost Warrior 2 is mostly around sniping, and all about infiltrating.
Sniping is quite challenging since distance, gravity and wind affect your shots. Luckily, out of Expert difficulty, a red dot appears on your crosshairs indicating where the bullet will land. Your best shots can even be seen from a bullet traveling perspective, which makes this quite entertaining.

Sadly, there are still many improvements to do.
Stealth is not very reliable, since plants sometimes hide you and sometimes not, like with some hard obstacles. Unless with a teammate AI guiding you, it's often better to eliminate all enemies before crossing the area.
AI is pretty simplistic, your teammate often not covering you, enemies staying hidden while they can't locate you or run towards you when they spot you, not caring about your allies.
Some gameplay is pretty frustrating, like not being able to switch between crouch and prone (you must be standing first), nor to switch weapons when aiming down sights. Maps are fairly long and decently detailed, but also show some problems, like some obstacle close just enough to block your way or preventing you from advancing while prone. Including corpses.
The story is quite clich√© and not detailed. The many cutscenes don't help it and are here mostly trying to give an epic feeling, but pretty much fail to do so. It's also disappointing said cutscenes are pre-rendered videos, at low quality, and sometimes laggy (not joking).

Overall, it's decent game if you want some sniping experience, if you have some time to spare waiting for something else.

reviewText:
If you want an experience that makes you think on your feet, adapt, improvise, and overcome, DO NOT play Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2. I had hopes that they would have improved from the first game, I was wrong. I played the game on hard difficulty right off the bat. The game was easy since they held your hand all the way through. So, really there was no tension within the gameplay to keep you on the edge of your seat. Not to mention, the story isn't even worth reading in a book, much less have it play out for you within the game.

Basically, the gameplay consisted of sniping from a fixed position, and then moving on to the next position, then repeat. The most challenging sniping segment comes in the first act of the game, which consisted of 3 acts. The gameplay involved in moving on to the next position is very boring, since again, they hold your hand the entire time. It tries to be a mini game of stealth during these segments but fails miserably. Think of those goofy shooting gallery games at a carnival where you just stand there and try to hit as many targets as possible, combine that with amazing graphics from Cryengine 3, and that's pretty much the game in a nutshell.

In my opinion, a sniper game needs to be non-linear mostly where tactics play a large role in how well the mission turns out. I have played Sniper Elite (love it), Sniper Elite V2 (could've been 100x better), and Sniper: Ghost Warrior 1. Out of all of them, Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2 would have to be my least favorite. However, it does have the best eye candy. If this game used the non-linear style of Sniper Elite combined with the Cryengine 3 graphics, it would've been an amazing experience. I did play the DLC Siberian Strike, however, it was only a minimal improvement over the main campaign's gameplay. I didn't even touch the multiplayer, I had no desire to do so. I apologize to the game designers and production team for a bad review, but you deserved it. Games are to be active experiences, they are not to be passive experiences where the option of choice is a minimal factor. Obviously, this game was made just to serve as a way to make some money by cashing in on the masses playing other shooters or possibly to give some new people a chance at making a game with a great engine to design it from. reviewText:
If you liked the first you will like the second. If you didn‚Äôt then there is little here that will likely change your mind.

The formula is almost the same but the pacing and level design are much improved. In fact, level design, graphic style and the locations for each act are extremely well done. Each has a different atmosphere and feel that helps build tension and excitement. It is a shame that SGW2 is actually so short a game. Given time and resources you can only wonder at just what City Interactive might have achieved.

Whilst there are limited choices in terms of level exploration it is painfully evident you are playing an on rails shooter. You never really shake the corridor shooter feel and the ever present way point indicator only serves as a reminder of just how much you are being funnelled through the game.

The stealth elements of the game are not infuriatingly complex or overly sensitive to the slightest misstep. However, the few times stealth becomes the play style of choice it is more often than not because it might serve as an easier alternative to simply running in guns blazing. Once again, the lack of a more open world with multiple paths to your objective is more the culprit than the actual mechanics for stealth which are generally pretty good. You just never really have the space to truly explore options to avoid more of the combat.

The AI is largely there to be killed with minimal fuss and will provide token gestures of resistance whilst being as accommodating as possible to someone armed with a sniper rifle. This is, however, a relative blessing. Were it more proficient in trying to kill you it would only prove just how mind-blowingly useless your spotter is at trying to aid and protect you.

Hidden secret items make a return and each act will have a different item to look out for and collect. That said, I‚Äôm not at all certain what bonus or benefit you gain from spending time looking for them beyond satisfying any OCD tendencies you might have.

The single player campaign offers up about 4 hours worth of entertainment so this isn't a game you'll be with for long unless you're planning on spending time with the multiplayer. The multiplayer is entertaining and certainly, so far as I was concerned, offered far more for my money.

Whilst I enjoyed playing through Sniper Ghost Warrior 2 I also felt cheated out of my money. The game is just too short, offers to little in the way of gameplay and left me simultaneously wanting more and glad I gotten it out of the way. Wait for it to appear in a 50% off or better sale before picking up. At full price there are better sniper games and certainly better FPS games available. As a cheap title picked up in a sale to enjoy as a multiplayer game amongst friends between more time consuming or in-depth games, it's a game I'd strongly consider. With the right people SGW2 could potentially be a lot of fun though ultimately it will only ever be a game that you play every now and then.

reviewText:
While I do recommend this game, it does come with some caveats.

I'll start by saying that the first game was better than this one. I enjoyed the first one a lot better than this version.
Even the Siberian Strike DLC played okay, except for a forced combat section.

In 18 hours, I played the main game and the DLC. That is kind of disappointing considering the game. I honestly did think that this second game would improve from the first and WANTED it to be more than anything.

The play seemed clunky in places and at one scripted point, the binoculars were meant to  be in front of me and I was standing up, unable to bring them back up ( I was able to break out of the scripted sequence).

For the record, I played on medium throughout and just went with the flow of the game. When they hurried, I did. When they relaxed, I did. I did do a lot of stealth knife kills.

On the plus side, when I hit my marks, they felt satisfying and even nicking them in the side of the neck shows an evil, borderline psychotic love of the animation as they struggle and wriggle at the sudden loss of blood then life.

Under thermals, the bodies react as expected as they lose life and heat in the DLC. The caves and indoor areas were pitch ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing black and rightly so. CryEngine 3 is really good even on sub-gaming rigs (like mine). While the settings weren't ultra hyper real 4k 3d zomg real lifeorz, it was easy to get immersed with the ambient sounds. Physics were almost perfect with some final corpse positions kinda dubious. But then again, my scope wasn't 12x so, couldn't see that far.

I satisfying it a 1572m mark with it, however and the bullet time captured the moment beautifully.
It does sound like I'm bashing the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• out of it and you could equally argue that I am but I don't feel bitter about it. More wanting, than anything. While adding content for the sake of adding content is in the Gamer's Cardinal Sin book (volume 3), I felt like I wanted to be more snipery (if that makes sense).

TL;DR: A good, solid sniper game with lots of action and beautiful scenery. This would be a solid buy, but replay IMO isn't high - so bear that in mind before you pull the trigger.

Oh and two more things: Load last checkpoint is your friend most times and millimetres matter. Good hunting ;)

Definitely a sniping game you'd want to give a shoot to, literally.
It's good for once to find a sniping game providing you exactly with what it advertised in the first place... you know, sniping. About time I'd say. You are not a lone Rambo-kind-a-guy playing the last man standing in close quarters with a damn sniper rifle. This time around you are actually a support unit, either accompanied with a spotter or directed remotely by the intelligence. Those few occasions in which you are alone always allow you to go ahead at your own pace and pick targets from one of a few safe positions. Sometimes you get to run for your life but that's part of the game (pun not intented).
It feels a very well-scripted campaign overall, running a quite smooth operation with proper intelligence, like it was really set up by some agency for you to have all info at your disposal. Small plot twists and various secondary inconveniences just add up to a cool gaming experience.

PS. Don't bother with the first Sniper game, it has a few good sniping sessions, but overall it feels more like a generic B-series FPS with sniper rifles only and small maps. Kind of annoying.

reviewText:
The shooting range is the best part of this game, although it is not a standard shooting range. The shooting range is in of itself a single map that one selects a gun (and can swap them out) and then gets in position and snipes the actual targets... they are not cardboard cutout but actual 3d characters that are mobile. Wind is a factor in the game as is distance (gravity).

The campain for this game feels rushed. The gemetry/maps are built well (only had one instance that what diisplayed and what was got me... which was nice (every game has at least one if you explore as I do). The thing that makes it feel rushed is that there are many isntances where it says shoot X and I have no idea where X is, and they jsut keep repeating shoot X... which is especially difficult to look for when you are being shot at. Sometimes they effectively say what to target and where, most of the time they do not, however sometimes they are marked for you... Finally there is one instance where you have less than a second or 2 to snipe a very mobile target that if you don't hit you must retry it again, and again, and again... by the time I got it I think I quick scoped without any expectation of hitting the danged target... and in no way could effectively repeat the success.

It is not a bad campain or game, just can just lack its entertainment value at times.
If you can get this game for real cheap then go for it, otherwise I would not go out of your way for it. Cheap for me would be a buck or two... or grab it in a bundle of some sort if that is more economical for oneself.

reviewText:
-SINGLEPLAYER-
This might turn out to be a review for the awesome parts of the first game because, let's be honest, the first game was so much better than this. What were they thinking?! Let's talk about the story first - one word: Lame. It was so short and there was no obvious point to everything you were doing. It was so hard to follow. Oh, and just so you know, I review a game on it's gameplay, not on its graphical quality, although, I gotta say, the graphics were absolutely outstanding! However, that was really the only good thing about the game. The feel of the game with the sniper rifle and running around felt very clunky, even for a PC game - and where I would get around 60 - 80 FPS on high settings, I would still get this really irritating stutter glitch/bug (Had an FPS counter in top left corner of screen).

There was no sence of freedom to make your own decisions about infiltrating this place or killing these people. It was far too easy because you had that really annoying spotter sitting next to you the whole time telling you how to do it. No thinking is required. Also, it is without a shadow of a doubt THE MOST LINEAR GAME IN THE HISTORY OF GAMES. No exaggeration. You couldn't make the decision to go left or right to get to your location, no open-world aspects, all you could do was follow your spotter. I felt like a baby learning how to walk whilst playing this game. I could often guess what was going to happen next half the time. WHERE IS THE FUN IN ANY OF THAT?!

The story all felt very clich√© and hollywood movie esque. By that I mean it had three very American protagonists, played by, what sounded to be, low budget - somewhat amatuer voice actors.

And so on, blah blah blah. You could finish they campaign in just under 4 hours if you rushed it, which to be honest, I did because it was so boring I just wanted to get it over with.

-MULTIPLAYER-
The multiplayer for Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2 was all round extremely dull. There was nothing good to say about it to be honest. It's what you would expect from a sniper-based game: lots of camping, spending an age to find a target to shoot at, and when you eventually do find a target, they either move before you can get a shot, or you are shot first.

-OVERALL VERDICT-

Pros
-Stunning Graphics
-(Reasonably) Clever AI

Cons
-Short Story
-Boring Story
-Clich√© Story
-Same-old Story
-Clunky feel when playing
-Repetetive
-Dull Multiplayer (full of little kids squealing on the mic)
-NO WHERE NEAR AS GOOD AS THE FIRST GAME

-ADVICE-
Don't buy this game - spend your money on a better game, for example: The first one!

Thanks for reading.

reviewText:
Excellent game that took me completely by surprise.
It requires strategy, unlike a lot of other campain driven games. For instance, you take down the enemies that are not in line of sight of each other to remain hidden. If you are spotted you are in trouble and things become a lot more difficult, but you do not automatically fail. You can also choose to sneak around enemies and leave them alive, or take them out from close quarters.

This game is absorbing and highly entertaining. Don't expect a story like Call of Duty, or an insane graphical masterpiece.

Want a true challenge? Harder difficulties remove the aim dot. You need to check the wind strength and range, and then align your shot accordingly. This game mode immerses you even more.

The serbian strike DLC was great, but shorter than the main campain (as expected).

I have not played much of the multiplayer yet. There are a couple of servers that are active. Proper sniper battles.

I will buy the sequel, if there ever is one.

reviewText:
Before starting to play Sniper Ghost Warrior 2, my expectations were very high. I was expecting it to at least match the original game in terms of gameplay features. Unfortunately it failed to do this, and ultimately failed to meet the standards of the Cry Engine 3 (one of the most powerful engines currently available).

Similar to the way I felt before and after I started playing the game, I‚Äôll start with the good things and move on to the bad things and finish with the best part.

Sniper Ghost Warrior 2 does the sniping aspect very well.  There aren‚Äôt too many FPS games out there that focus on sniping, or at least, there aren‚Äôt any out there that have this much depth to sniping. The developers have done a superb job at creating a realistic sniping experience. Various measurements need to be taken before lining up the perfect shot and different locations mean different adjustments. Distance, wind, and even the curve of the bullet need to be taken into consideration. This makes sniping enemies very enjoyable and varied, depending on conditions.

The developer, City Interactive seemed to have focused perhaps too much on the sniping aspects of the game, because that‚Äôs about all that‚Äôs good about it :/ I‚Äôve noticed a lack of gameplay features that were present in the previous game such as, grapple hooking your way to high places, picking up enemy firearms, using throwing knives to take out enemies. The gameplay revolves completely around using your sniper rifle to well‚Ä¶‚Ä¶..snipe, and using your P220 pistol if things get up close and personal. The P220 features in all three of the chapters as a sidearm, but the primary sniper rifle changes depending on what chapter you‚Äôre playing. Apart from finding the occasional enemy Dragunov rifle, you have no other weapons to find or interact with.  This seriously upset me.

Level design is another issue with Sniper Ghost Warrior 2. The levels are detailed, but I feel this is just a way of disguising how painstakingly linear they are. Each chapter has you following a set path with a few open vistas to shoot enemies from a far. The vistas do offer fairly detailed locations to find and shoot enemies, but ultimately they just serve as complex shooting galleries and you never actually get to explore them. The levels are also too small. I find myself disappointed whenever I round a corner, only to realise that I‚Äôm in an even smaller house than the last one I was in. I was really hoping for a more open ended level design, but City Interactive has decided to play it safe and keep things way too simple.

Lastly, I‚Äôll talk about the multiplayer. This is the most surprising part about Sniper Ghost Warrior 2. It‚Äôs actually a decent addition to the game. I was highly expecting an equally lack luster experience online as I did with my campaign experience, but it turned out better than expected. Sniping is really the only feature in multiplayer, but it‚Äôs easier to enjoy due to the lack of a forced story or other cheesy scripted events. The multiplayer levels are really well designed, plenty of places to hide, plenty of choices for rifles to use, and plenty of intensity that should have been more common in the single player. Looking around the maps for enemies is a long and tiring process, but once you find one and line up the perfect shot, it‚Äôs all worth it. Hearing the bullet whizz past your head as another sniper takes shots at you, forcing you to relocate before it‚Äôs too late, that‚Äôs an awesome feeling too. It‚Äôs a nice break from the normal run and gun shooters out there, where the SMG class is king. In this case, less is more.

Overall I did enjoy Sniper Ghost Warrior 2. While it didn‚Äôt meet my expectations, it still does sniping better than any other game I‚Äôve played. I can see myself continuing to play the multiplayer, while waiting for the DirectX 11 patch to be released. I might get 10 more hours out of it if I‚Äôm lucky. If you‚Äôre a sucker for FPS games like me, this will be worth your time. If not, then you won‚Äôt be missing much.

6/10

reviewText:
One thing is certain: Sniper Ghost Warrior 2 is certainly more enjoyable than its predecessor. But is it that much better if you look closer ? No, but there are a few things that have been improved.
First of all, the game now runs on the CryEngine 3. It's definitely visible as the game looks more vibrant and detailed, but faces are still a bit low poly. And the environments, while they look frequently beautiful, are still not open. The game lets you walk in only one direction, so, like the first one, it's still linear. Not a big deal at all, but it would've been cooler if you had the chance to kill people from more than one location.

Another improvement is that it's more stealthy. In the first one there were a few moments where you had to kill (waves of) enemies using regular weapons, which was a bit odd considering the fact that it's a sniper game and it's called Sniper Ghost Warrior. SGW2 fixes that problem. You still get to switch to your handgun, but there are no other weapons besides that one and your trusty sniper rifle. Firefights are more intense because of that. Now, intense might not be the right word for it, because they aren't really, but you get the feeling you're playing as a real sniper. And while kills aren't as satisfying as sniping someone in Sniper Elite V2 it still does a good job of mixing up the action with some slow motion bullet kills. Even if they're not that spectacular.

The game consists of three acts, with several missions in each act. Missions will take somewhere between 10-30 minutes, and most of us will finish the game within 5,5 hours. It's not overly long and therefore stays enjoyable all the way through.

If you're into sniper games, like me, SGW2 might be worth your time and money. It all depends on how much of a fan you are. Still, if I had to choose between this game and Sniper Elite V2, Sniper Elite would win without a doubt. That doesn't mean it's bad, but it does mean there's still room for improvement.

[Rating: 70/100]

reviewText:
I enjoyed this sniper game, and I think you'll like it if you generally enjoy this type of game.  It took me 8 hours or so to complete the single player mode on easy difficulty.  Since I'm not a great player, it took some time and retries to clear the missions,  Having checkpoints to avoid starting over each time I died was good, but sometimes I wished there were a few more checkpoints, because there were a few times where I had to replay the same tedious or annoying parts over and over because I kept dying before reaching the next checkpoint.

The story here is broken up into three acts, each made up of a few missions, and you're working as part of a team even in single player mode.  I think the story developed well, and even though game play can be a little slow at times (e.g., sneaking into areas means crouch-walking for a long-ish time), I think that helps get you immersed in the story.  I think your only weapons here are a sniper rifle, a pistol (I think), and a knife.  While the knife is useful for doing silent kills, I don't think I ever really used the pistol.  The game kind of seems designed to keep you using the sniper rifle, which makes sense.  At a few points you have to set up on a sniping point from which you cannot move at all, which makes things a little more difficult if you get spotted and shot at, since you can't slide over at all to try to keep the enemies from guessing exactly where you are.  There are multiple difficulty levels, though I haven't tried any but the easy one, and a multiplayer mode, which I also haven't tried.  But the multiple modes and difficulties should make this game accessible to all sorts of players.

A few notes on this game (SGW2) compared to Sniper Elite V2 (SE2), which I played before this:  easy mode in SGW2 doesn't mean line up the enemies directly in the center of the cross-hairs like it does in SE2; there is bullet drop and wind effects, but there's a kind of aim-assist mechanism where a small red dot appears showing you where the bullet will go -- you line that dot up with where you want to shoot.  As noted above, although the game play in SGW2 is a little slower, I think I got into the story more.  You don't have as many weapons/tools here as in SE2, but then again, you're in a team here and solo there.  Also, it seems easier to stick with the sniper rifle here; a number of times in SE2, enemies would get close enough that I had to switch to another gun, but that didn't happen very much in SGW2.  Both games are good, but operate a little differently (as expected).

reviewText:
I got this in a bundle for $3, and it was totally worth that price. The singleplayer campaign is really unpolished, but there are some parts where it gives you a bit of freedom and these are often quite enjoyable. The game is also reasonably comitted to the sniper angle, and does it fairly well. You only ever get a sniper rifle and pistol, so you have to be stealthy. Occasionally, you actually have to think about the best way to accomplish that, and these sections are generally pretty good and evoke the patience and planning of a skilled sniper. At other times the game forces you into gunfights, and these suck. Enemies can kill you very easily, which is good for a stealth game but frustrating in an action game in which you have very little short-to-medium range firepower, since your pistol is crap and your rifle is always scoped and bolt-action. Still, a cautious and skillful player can avoid the great majority of these, so it's not a huge problem.

About the plot, not much can be said. Dull military bros shoot a bunch of dudes, and somebody's evil, and more dudes are shot. One level is set in Bosnia, which is pretty cool. I have no idea how historically accurate it is but it's nice to see some new settings being explored.

The game looks okay. It's got some nice CryEngine-y effects, but a lot of the assets are kinda fugly. Ultimately it gets the job done. Some of the level design is well-done, but checkpoint spacing is often poor, and manual saves are not allowed. Bugs crop up from time to time, everything from bullets passing harmlessly through enemies to your companion's AI simply not triggering, but it's not completely game-ruining.

Ultimately this is only for people who really like single-player shooters. It lacks the polish and bombast of stuff like Call of Duty, but it also lacks the flexibility and openness of games like Crysis or Far Cry 3. Still, for a budget developer it's a pretty solid release, and bodes well for a third game. I wouldn't recommend it at $20, as it's just not polished enough, but for $10 or less it's worth a shot.

reviewText:
Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2 is many things and the thing that attracted me was the sniping aspect of the game, as the name suggests. Let me explain: this game does look a lot better than its predecessor and that's thanks to Cryengine 3. That being said, most other aspects of this game are average at best. Voice acting is okay...nothing spectacular and the same goes for AI. The story is not really engaging and there is virtually no character development.

Now for the part you're waiting to hear about: the sniping. Few games capture the true feel of sniping (here I'm speculating, having never been a sniper or anything of the sort) as this game does. When you approach a combat situatuon there are several things you must consider: 1.) Your surroundings. Are you exposed or hidden? Do you have a good grasp of the area or are you working on limited information? 2.) Your heartbeat. This effects your shots. To be the most accurate, you must wait for your heartbeat to lower or you will have major bobbing of the scope. 3.) Distance and wind direction. On the lower difficulties, the game will assist you with this aspect. I play on the hardest, this means no assist. You must assess the range and power of the wind and take your shot accordingly. This is where the game shines in my opinion.

Of course, you can just shoot without taking these things into consideration but this retracts from the game I think. Sniper: Ghost Warrior wants you to think like a sniper and if you do, you will be rewarded with the satisfaction of making that perfect shot.

reviewText:
A huge improvement over the first one with every criticism from the first one fixed.

If you played the 1st ghost warrior:

+No crappy CQC sections where you have to gun down enemies with a crappy assault rifle
+Ai is a bit smarter and it shows
+Very few bugs and glitches (there was a small glitch with detection, not gamebreaking)
+Better voiceacting (+Troy Baker = Protagnist)
+You only play as a sniper, not a spotter or foot soldiers, just sniper
+No instant fail states(you will probably just die though from just getting detected and getting .50 calibar tatoos)

Overall:

Pros:
+You actually feel like a vulnerable sniper/immersion
+Great environments
+The shooting and physics feel great
+Stealth is a requirement

Cons:
-Short and very linear
-You only get around 3 different sniper rifle and 1 pistol for the entire game
-Ai is still a bit dumb
-Final Boss is still a bit easy and lackluster

As of this review, the game is 20 USD. I would recommend it at that price, but no more

reviewText:
In short: A good game but do not buy full priced.

Pro's
-Nice gameplay if you like sneaking and sniping. Defenitely better real 'sniping' experience than for example Sniper Elite. It tries to be somewhat of a sniper simulator but can't really deliver there like ARMA does. However in the context of this game it is enough to make gameplay very interesting and even challenging.
-Pretty decent graphics and nice environments.
-Story not very good but interesting enough.


Con's
-Badly optimised. Although my computer is absolutely fine (can run all games i know at high/very high) this game did not feel fluid. Especially when running it felt weird, a kind of stuttering or something.
-Bugs. This game has its share of bugs. Usually nothing game-breaking but i once could not pick up my gun and the keys to change stance seem to randomly make you crouch, stand or go prone which is very annoying.
-VERY VERY Linear. you don't have any choice to do anything. You can complete the objective in one way and no other.
-Voice acting is a little dull sometimes
-That red dot. The only thing making this game a challenge is aiming. With the red dot enabled (when looking through your scope it gives the exact place you are going to hit) there is absolutely no challenge. There really should be a way of disabling it without having to play on the hardest difficulty. The same goes for the hints and everything.
-Companion AI is bad. When following a companion they always run. I could barely catch up with them and usually i just played my own style and they would just stand and wait out in the open until i catched up.

Conclusion
It is a decent game for a few hours of fun. It gives a pretty good sniping experience where your skill will matter (if you play on hard so disable aim assist). It defenitely immerses you in the role of a sniper. Get it when it is in the sale and you will not regret your purchase

reviewText:
I was gifted this game by a friend on steam, as he had got a code for this from somewhere. I was suprised upon starting the game at how good it was. It really is quite a fun game and the stealth concept is great.

Criticisms :
The campaign is quite short, I finished it in about 5 hours.
I feel that there should have been more player based control, especially during the missions where you just simply pick off the targets that have been selected.
Multiplayer isn't very active - I did manage to get onto one game and it was alright, but i feel the concept was not advanced enough.
Your team AI not always that briliant when you are in combat (Fully detected)
Came across a few problems, including what appeared to be an invisable barrier at the top of a ladder, aswell as some of the dialoge being cut off.

Pros:
Good graphics
Runs fine, although probably wont do great on low spec systems
Immersive campaign - Such a shame it was so short.
There is a multiplayer option, so could be fun if you play with friends.
The AI you play with really does make it feel so much more Co-op rather than being lonely
10/10 Would reccomend when on sale.
7/10 Would reccomend at current price.

This game had Super potentiel. Theres a lot of gorgeos level design, many nice details and of course sniping.
However, if you play on any but the hardest diffultcy theres a lot of help- too much with a small red circle revealing bullet impact, and threat indicators.

In this game you only get to engage fairly few at the time and they are always bunched up. Theres far too much running behing some NPC and rushing through pretty levels with only ever ONE path.

I had high hopes, but they were quickly dashed. Go for Sniper elite 3 for a better sniper game.

The total lack of custemisation of guns, bullet grain and no time or good tools to really calculate windtage or bullet drop ..well sigh.

Last but not least I compelated this game on hard in just 5.1 hours - far to quickly for a sniper game.
Get this on sale if you like the action sniper" genre.

reviewText:
I avoided this game for some time because of the poor early review scores.  I can't comment on whether the inital reviews were justified or the extent of any bugs which were subsequently fixed.  What I can say is that this is not a bad game.  I've played through the single-player campaign (about 7 hours) and the Siberian Strike DLC (about 2.5 hours) and had a fair amount of fun doing it.

Overall, I thought it offered a nice, if over the top, narrative and reasonable stealth / sniper mechanics.  Much of the criticism of the game centers on its linear nature.  On that count, it's guilty as charged.  You will never confuse this game with Far Cry 3 in terms of open world mechanics.  That said, there are plenty of games that offer a fun experience in a linear fashion.  While the encounters are essentially all set-piece they are nicely designed.  I'm still not sure what the campaign was doing in Tibet, but it was terrifically rendered.

I'd define the highs and lows as follows:

Highs:
Solid graphics (better than average PC options for a port)
Good sniper gameplay
Reasonable level of player decisioning (no penalties if you decide to alert the enemy rather than being stealthy)
Logical controls
Good range of difficulty levels
Essentially bug-free as far as I could tell

Lows:
A little short
A wonky checkpoint or two (nothing game breaking)
Occasional unaware enemies (walking past bodies with no reaction)

Overall, I had a good time playing through the campaign and DLC and will probably do so again.  If you are looking for a sniper game specifically, I would probably recommended Sniper Elite: V2 over this one but only by a small margin.  If you catch this one on a periodic Steam sale for less than $10, I wouldn't hesitate to pick it up along with the Siberian Strike DLC.

reviewText:
Sniper Ghost Warrior 2

Plusy:

-Dobra grafika , nowy silnik gry , ktory chodzi calkiem dobrze.
-Fantastycznie pokazany lot kuli , ktora zaraz przeswidruje na wylot czaszke przeciwnika.
-Fajna kampania , przyjemna i wciagajaca na dlugie godziny.
-Brag bugow , na multiplayerze na mapie ''Kurort'' jest kilka glitchy , ktore mogli by naprawic.
-Dobrze odwzorowane modele broni , jak i ich lunety od srodka.
-Kilka trybow multiplayer . takich jak , Hard , Hardcore i Normal. (Ponizej wytlumacze o co w nich chodzi).

Minusy:

-Zbyt krotka kampania jak dla mnie , przeszedlem ja w dwie godziny , na srednim poziomie trudnosci.
-Za malo map , multiplayer , wszyscy znaja tzw. campy i to psuje przyjemnosc z gry.
-Brak oficjalnych i stabilnych serverow , najwyzej sa hosty , robione przez graczy.
-Postac zbyt szybko sie meczy , przebiegniemy lub skoczymy raz na jakis przedmiot i tetno skacze nam do 160 , rozumiem , obladowany amunicja i bronia , ale napewno po jednym skoku odrazu sie tak nie meczymy. Dlatego postanowilem dodac to do minusow.

Jak powyzej napisalem o trzech trybach mp (multiplayer) , takze wyjasnie o co w nich chodzi:

Hardcore - Mamy dosc malo HP , brak komunikacji , pisemnej jak i glosowej , nie wyswietla sie nam podpowiedz gdzie spadnie pocisk , trzeba samemu dokladnie wycelowac , po czym strzelic.

Hard- Mamy srednia ilosc HP , komunikacja glosowa jak i pisemna jest , i tak jak powyzej nie wyswietla sie nam podpowiedz gdzie spadnie pocisk.

reviewText:
tl,dr: Shooting feels good, but the other gameplay elements are ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• and the game is buggy and inconsistent.

So I kind of liked the first Sniper: Ghost Warrior, the only bad taste I remember was the ending which was a little underwhelming, gameplay wise.

I am strictly going to talk about gameplay because the story is just some Modern Military shooter garbage.

The actual shooting is alright, the pistol (your secondary is able to kill in one shot, unless you are in combat then it sometiems takes two) and the sniper's rifle oneshots aswell, unless you shoot people in their hands. It feels pretty good to line up a shot with a decent range and some wind and just place a bullet in centermass.

However, the game is quite buggy and the checkpoints are odd and inconsistent.
In one of the earlier missions you are placed in a high advantage point with a very high powered sniper's rifle like a .50 cal or something. Not only do people not hear the shots even though it is only 300 meters away, but I was actually placed slightly below the surface on which I was supposed to lie on.

The stealth is weird and inconsistent sometimes you can just hide in some slightly shadowy area and you are completely invisible to the enemy whereas other times they can see through planks and bushes. It may have something to do with playing on the hardest difficulty I am not entirely sure.

The point that made me uninstall the game, was when I was supposed to shoot a pilot (inside a helicopter) from a decent  range and good amount of wind, but I only had like 4 seconds to do so giving me time for like 2 or 3 shots. I failed and had to do a bunch of stuff again, failed again and now the checkpoint was right next to the pilot-sniping, however I had no weapon so I couldn't even try it.

reviewText:
Surprisingly good.

Although a short game (only three mission arcs that are all relatively quick), it does provide what's written on the box - A game focussed around being a sniper. It has a good mix of sneaking and shooting, and the levels where you don't have a spotter are suitably challenging. Playing it on anything less than Expert is a waste, since the bullet impact indicator makes long range sniping far too easy. Pulling off a 1,400 metre headshot on Expert mode is, however, suitably satisfying.

The graphics are absolutely astounding. The third mission arc is set in a Nepalese monastery, and the scenery looks straight out of a travel book. That said, I'd not expect anything short of gorgeous on the Crysis 2 engine.

reviewText:
Solid sniping mechanics and great graphics brought down by bland protagonists and an extremely linear experience.  You play as several different characters and use a variety of rifles, but there was no difference between any of them (well, OK, the rifles each held a different number of bullets.  Which is at least more variety than the main characters had to tell them apart.)

With a few exceptions, every mission has you being led by an AI spotter who will tell you when/where to move and when/whom to shoot.  Fall behind and the spotter will yell at you to catch up, speed ahead and the game will stonewall you.  Either with a dead end where you can only proceed once your spotter catches up and tells you what door to open (yes, really), all enemies suddenly on high alert (even if you're in the same place your spotter would tell you to stand 3 seconds later), or a straight up mission failed for no reason" screen.

Shooting targets out of order would have a similar effect.  All enemies would suddenly go on high alert (even when shooting lone targets out of sight of anyone else) or enemies would be straight up invulnerable until you went back and shot everyone in the order the game wanted you to.
The few sections where you are separated from your spotter really show how much this game could have shined as a stealth-sniping-action-shooter hybrid.  There's one part where your spotter gets captured and you set off alone to rescue him.  You run through several arenas where you can engage multiple enemies at your own pace.  It really really underscored how good the game could have been
date: if only they'd given the player some freedom.\n\nUltimately
recommended: there is too little player input required and the game is too linear to recommend to anyone outside of the "sniping mechanics in a rail shooter" niche.\nDisclaimer:  My only play through was on Medium difficulty and I did not try the multiplayer."

reviewText:
First things first, I bought this game solely for the multiplayer.

This game is a great improvement over the first, but my singleplayer experience was ruined by various bugs and glitches.
They started off small in the beginning of the game, small graphics glitches, floating objects, getting stuck on terrain, etc.
Near the end of the game I ran into something awful. The game literally crashed my computer during one of the cutscenes. My pc can max this game without breaking a sweat, and this wasn't a crash to desktop, the computer completely turned off. When I powered back up my save file was corrupt. This is why I haven't even finished the single player yet, even though it is so short.

Was I devasted? Not really, multiplayer was unaffected in any way. The multiplayer experience in Sniper Ghost Warrior 2 is an enjoyable one, if you enjoy sniping. Matches are around 20 minutes long and often never score higher than 15 or so kills. The sniping mechanics are really great in this game.

Pros
+Good mechanics
+AR/SMG sections of first game are gone
+Multiplayer is fun
+Environments are very nice looking

Cons
-Poor story
-Very buggy
-Lack of a multiplayer community, theres hardly ever more than one server
-Crashes for unknown reasons
-Character models look horrendous

As I bought this game for the multiplayer, I would reccomend the multiplayer portion to a friend. As far as the single player experience goes, try out any of the Sniper Elite titles.

reviewText: Worst fricking game of all time, DO NOT BUY, SAVE YOURSELF THE MONEY and IGNORE. It has terrible performance, and a cruddy multiplayer. Can't even switch your pistol for an assault rifle, just in case! Also, the guy must wear like a frickin t-shirt because you die in like 1 hit, even on full health. The companion's AI is terrible, they do literally nothing for the player, or the game. The most common companion I've seen is Diaz and he gets an assault rifle, but goes for the least threatening guy when your cought. Checkpoints are few and far between at points where they are the most necessary, but every other hallway you encounter in the least necessary situations. You will find that even though your guy is a sniper and must have a strong arm, you cannot hold your rifle still even while crouching, which is when you are generally using it, and going prone generally leads to a tiny ledge in the way from bad level design, so you have to crouch and end up missing. I found myself often missing an easy target because a wooden plank is preventing me from going prone to be steadier. The graphics are acceptible, and in fact probably better than Call of Duty, and it has an interesting story, with a great sense of actually sniping, except for the stability. The best part is how your bullet drops with distance and is very affected by the wind, though I wish the little circle showing where the bullet will land would always be visible, as I often find myself looking around a target trying to find the dot. I've had frequent crashes, once caausing my entire computer to crash, so that is upsetting. Then after restarting your computer / the game, you need to sit through 4 different company thingies that you get at the beginning of most games that tell you who sponsored / help made the game and what engine it runs which are all unskippable. If they were skippable or only one or two, it would be OK, but there's four. FOUR! Thats over 20 seconds just waiting to get to the main menu!!! UNACCEPTABLE! So, to recap, I buy a game, have it not work, and have a serious game breaking graphical bug that gets fixed (without changing a thing) a few days later, only to have it crash, then sit through the company ad things all over again. I bought this game in the Bundle Stars Sniper Ghost Warrior Pack for $2.99, and now I know why it was priced that way. I can't believe they make you pay extra for DLC for one of the worst multiplayers ever!! 2 out of 10 stars.

This is a game that would have done far better as a movie.

However, the level design was very nice. Unlike the first game, you're not stuck in a jungle the whole time, you actually get to experience urban combat. Extremely satisfying as a sniper.

There is no CoD-esque combat like in the first game. You stick purely to your rifle and pistol, which in this game was the best way to go. (Obviously.)

The A.I. is average, along with the dialogue and story, and characters.

I would say all around it's a good game, and would recommend it to anyone who enjoys an action packed sniper game with a few silly quirks.

Serious bugs prevented me from getting anywhere in this game. Search online and you'll see many others reporting the same thing: Enemies and certain environmental objects are sometimes completely invisible. They're not supposed to be invisible; this is a bug. I tried DX9 and DX11 and other settings, and I could not work around this bug.

I also had an issue with the NPC I was supposed to be following simply coming to a complete stop, which prevented the game from progressing. There was no way for me to get it going again other than to lose progress, reload, and hope it didn't happen again. But it kept happening again and again, at different points in the game.

Both bugs were infuriating. This game was worse than a complete waste of money: I essentially paid to get angry.
Broken as ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, only paid 5 bucks for it. Five bucks I will never get back. How the hell is it possible to release such a broken game?

I was expecting a great looking, open-worldish, sniper shooter. Instead I got a linear restricted and buggy experience.  The fact that it was made in cryengine seems to mean nothing as its textures remind me of early cod. However as a casual shooter with no care for deep story or customisability, it isn't too bad.  The sniping is realistic, bullet drop and wind correction are amazingly accurate and the constant changing of vantage points give you motivation to take down as many targets as possible so you are clear to move.  It also has a slight crysis 1 / far cry 3 feel at times which can create a sense of comfort every now and then.

Remember how awesome Call Of Duty 4 was? Remember that level where you run through Pripyat as a sniper and take out the bad guy with your .50? Basically that. An entire game of that. Just that.

With a bug list that rivals Goat Simulator and a story so easy to predict it left me wincing, Sniper: Ghost Warrior is back.
The original Sniper: Ghost Warrior game was terrible. You can argue that all you want but having played it myself and not gotten a refund, I won't listen. The shooting mechanics offer some variety on the higher difficulty settings but overall the lack of challenging shots leaves a lot to be desired. The positioning aspect of the game amounts to walking along a predetermined path to painfully obvious hides. You take out a few waves of enemies with your high powered rifle. You move on to the next level.

While this is no-punches-pulled for what the game advertises, I find it hard to justify the price when a much more competent competitor lets you enjoy shooting Hitler between the legs. If you want a ballistics simulation get either Sniper Elite v2 or Arma 3.

If you want that Pripyat level of Call of Duty for an entire game, look no further.

First of all, CI games did many weird things these years. They own CryEngine and develop Ghost Warrior 2 with it. But they switched to UE 3 to develop Alien Rage, and when they cooperated with Deck 13, all of sudden, they had an in-house engine to develop Lords of the Fallen. I still cannot figure out why they don't have consistency in development cycles.
Aside from that, here is my review.
1. Graphics looks terrible. It is not about DX9 or the CryEngine. I don't know, but it looks bad.
2. sound effects are pretty good I have to admit, and the voice acting is good as well.
3. Too many bugs and glitches. Sometimes, bugs happened just before the checkpoint, when that happens, every time you reload to last checkpoint, the bugs will take effects making it unplayable and you can only start the entire level again.
4. Gameplay is ok, using sniper rifle is fun. But this is not a good sniper or stealth game.
5. There must be something wrong with this game. It really feels like playing COD. The level intro looks like MW 1&2.
I know this is a military game, but Splinter Cell Blacklist has the level intro which feels different, and BF's level intro is different either.
In conclusion, this game is not bad but not good, just average to play, maybe you can find something you like in this game, and when it is on sale, maybe a good purchase. 5.5/10

I don't know why I've overlooked the review of this game for so far, but here it goes. This game is good, semi-realistic sniper shooter, FPS-experience with awsome graphics and without any major flaws. It is very pleasant and enjoyable game that has extremely low learning curve (even on hardest difficulty) offering something new to the usual FPS-games. I don't want to say that it gives totally new perspectives since there are many good snipers shooters out there already, sniper elite for one. It requires a gamer which veers of from mainstream games. It isn't fast paced or loaded with xp and leveling systems that unlock new shitey after few kills.\n\nThe combat mechanic is pretty basic and keyboard mapping is simple and easy to use. This makes the gameplay very solid and control of your character is responsive and the game doesn't feel sluqqish. Although sometimes I think devs lost a part of their imagination and this game got trambled by major FPS-shooters. Most of the maps are actually simple hallway"-runs consisting of boring tasks: " get to point A to B ". Additional points for doing this undetected. In small doses that is ok. The game has nice
recommended: not like in cod in which you can sneak pass of platoon of infantry and tanks in ghillie-suit without being noticed whilst communicating with your partner (which I think was ridiciolous). In the hardest difficuly you will get spotted very easily. I would like to think that is realistic
hoursPlayed: and when that happens you are in really bad situation. But you are given a choice
voteText: you can go stealth or you can go guns blazin'. The sniping experience itself is done nicely and is semi-realistic. I crouch with the dark and griity floor, my heartbeat goes into the triple digits, I lock and load my sniper rifle, I take aim, steady my breathing, and pull the trigger.

As I was playing Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2 I eager to try out a new form of gameplay. As a Gamer I never had a chance to try out how to become a sniper so this game was definitely a can opener to what awaits me.

Needless to say I was far from dissapointed.

Yes, the campaign was short, however the play-through was thrilling and tension breaking.

Trying to complete mission parameters wilthout letting the enemy know of your position and being as stealthy as possible will test your patience and skill with the gun itself.

Many times I wander WHY THE HELL DID I JUST GO RAMBO!??

Only to realize duh, your supposed to wait, then strike when the time is right.

I would ill advise the impatient, guns-blazing, hero maniacs out there because YOU WILL GET SHOT DOWN. it only takes several hits to even take you down few if hit in vital areas.

But, I digress, those out there that have the patience of iron will I challenge your stealth and patience and most of all determination to blaze through this game without healing once, or being detected, step it up a notch by cranking it up to it's max difficulty and you've got a hard-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• game that will make your eyes squint on your monitor.

Multiplayer is tediuous, many times your enemies and your teammates will camp and search for your enemy. Or the enemy will get tired of waiting and go through enemy lines Rambo style with a pistol.

Eh, To be honest, did teach a perspective for noobie snipers of just how hard a sniper's job really is, a small glimpse, but a worthy immersion into this unforgiving world where one bullet is all it takes to kill a soul.

Hesitate and you will fail, steady yourself or else all will be for naught, be aware of your surroundings, for you never know what lurks in the dark, and hopefully you'll live another day without a bullet through your head yesterday.

Don't jump the gun so soon...

I honestly thought that City Interactive was going to use this oppotunity at a sequel to address the issues and lukewarm reactions to the first game. Unfortunately it appears that most of the game's budget was siphoned into using the CryEngine 3 graphics engine (Crysis 2) but despite having such a proven utility at their disposal they only managed to create an alright looking game that still encounters consistent technical issues ranging from texture pop, to visual anomolies, and textures just not loading properly.

Beyond this the gameplay has remained much the same save for the exclusion of multiple player characters and sections devouted to being traditional first person shooters. This is a good thing though as the first game executed these things terribly.

The characters are bland, the voice acting is crap, the story is standard military-thriller fare and isn't original or groundbreaking, and the whole thing might take you three or four hours to complete...overall Ghost Warrior 2 is just a mediocre experience.

As previously stated. If you get it for under $10 it'll probably serve as a nice distraction but don't expect to be blown away.
