52 / 100 ? What. If you 're reading this , look pass the score. it doesnt make much sence, I even saw people gave it '0' in metacritic.com Don't hate it , try it first. Sniper : Ghost warrior 1 is a crap. And i concured on that. But This one is something you should try. The singleplayer campaign can deliver you more fun than Battlefield 3 (singleplayer) 's.There 're some of the 'Call of Duty moments too , lots of Hollywood - driven scenes'

Some people might think 'Hey if this game is as fun as those others good FPS (+ Sniping / Stealth) , then what's new in it?' My answer is Beside the fact that you have more chance to snipe and sneaking / crawling than other FPS games , No. Nothing new here. But Why not ? Why not get it if you saw the price drop to 7$ , 4.99$ ? Like i did. And I have to say that it's FUN.

Pros :

-Beautiful graphic (Thanks to CryEngine3) in ACT 1 - forest , it's kinda dark and too greenish there but after that in Bosnia and Tibet (ACT 2 - 3) The graphic will start to shine. As good as - better than Battlefield 3 / Medal of Honor 2012. I really like Bosnia and Tibet. The level designing , the buildings and those decorations are an art , espacially Tibet , VERY stunning.

-Bulletcam made a comeback.

-Storyline is ok , nothing special but not bad either.

-You always carry either Thermal cam or Night Vision one , Which are very useful to use in nearly every chapters. Good + fun tool.

-Improved AI , they 're way smarter than the previous one , when you start shooting , they will duck and get to the nearest cover. and try to swarm you from multiple directions if they have a chance.

-Realistic bulletdrop

-Good voice acting.

-A lot of Cut scene.

-Realistic HP , even in medium difficulty you can still die easily within 2 sec. if you got spray'd by enemy rifles.

-Sniping + play like a Hitman is fun and satisfying.


Cons :

-Length , it's short. Singleplaye clocked around 5 hours and 1.5 hours for the DLC (Based on my Medium difficulty gameplay)

-Multiplayer is kinda empty.

-Unrealistic enemies at some chapters e.g. You are about to engage large group of enemies from Hilltop with Unsuppressed Barette XM500 Sniper rifle. You followed what AI told you to do. When you shot an Ememy he told u to. Another enemies who stood around 20 m. next to there still acted the same (stay on  their course like nothing happen). even your gun is unsuppressed O_O

-You will never have a chance to use some cool sniper rifles (VSS Vintorez , DSR-50 , Accuracy International Arctic warfare 50) because they saved it for the multiplayer and yet multiplayer is deserted and empty , so. you lost that chance eventually.

*PS. The Singleplayer DLC 'Siberian Strike' have more things to offer. Huge map , Good post - soviet vibe of Siberia , because of the size of the map you can create your own strategy of killing.


7.4 / 10

This game has many enjoyable aspects to it, such as the pretty great feeling when sniping, the good- looking graphics and the amazing killcams over 1000 meters.

However - the singleplayer campaign was one of the worst campaigns in video game history that I have ever played.

The whole thing felt extremely forced upon you - no way to do anything by yourself. Literally every stealth kill you take is dictated. While I generally enjoy linear games for their great attention to detail and often great storytelling, this game has neither of these aspects, but still is one of the most linear shooters I have ever seen, leading to a rather boring experience that makes you feel like the clown in a theater play.

The story is uninspired - I didn't care at all about any of the NPCs in the game, at any point - I probably couldn't name any name from the campaign right now. The voice acting however is pretty solid, but nothing special. The characters did not evolve in any real way, I could pretty much tell from the beginning what they were going to act like.

The mechanics in the SP campaign are standard- esque. I enjoy the fact that the game does not have regenerating health, and requires you to at least somewhat care about medpacks. You actually die from very few shots, even on easier difficulities. The stealth mechanic however felt a little awkward for me at times - you could literally play peek-a-bo with a wall of enemies from behind a ledge, and none of the enemies would even blink. What's missing here is a visible curiousity" state in between unaware and spotted
date: where enemies go to check out something suspicious they believe they have seen.\n\nSo
recommended: all in all - if you're for some quick sniper action without any real depth

I don't blame the lameness on the developers though, but on the community.
Most of the people just wanted to spawn, find a good spot and then lie there staring at the building with the enemies on the other side of the map until they eventually spotted an enemey and fired or got fired upon and died without noticing where it came from.
To add another dimension to this, and perhaps to counter this kind of boring gameplay, the developers have added the possibility to cross an open field and get to the enemies house on the other side.
That was a good thing i thought. That would add a risk of camping and just staring down a scope, or hiding too well so you cant get a good overview - for ex to spot an enemy crossing.
Crossing the field to the enemys would indeed be risky, but if you manage you would get an advantage on people staring blindly down their scopes. This could also be a benefit for your own team, as you would 'stir things up' in the enemies building, causing them to move and thereby opening up shots for your team.

The game looks, plays, and feels like Call of Duty, except the only weapon you get to use is a sniper rifle. There are several different kinds of sniper rifles (MSR, M24, M82A1, etc.), but the only other weapon you have to use is a suppressed pistol, firing which feels like shooting a BB gun. The voice acting is horribly bad, and I do mean BAD. The game is almost played for you unless you are playing on the hardest difficulty. Everything is spelled out for you almost exactly, including where to go, who to kill and in what order, and where every last enemy is. On that note, enemies are lifeless. You might as well be shooting at mannequins. They will randomly spew out different phrases in Russian(?), from, I believe, a pool of set quotes. This being an FPS I'm not too surprised. The game also 'borrows' tricks and gimmicks from Call of Duty 4 rather frequently... I won't give any spoilers though.

Despite all this, environments are verdant and, though linear, well-designed as far as visuals go. The sniper aspect is, though somewhat inaccurate, challenging enough; firing a shot at the wrong time will have several automatic rifles firing in your direction, a bit pulse-pounding, but this is easily avoided, because, even though bullets can fly straight through enemies and hit a piece of metal behind them, resulting in a loud 'pang' sound, this will still not alert them. In fact I'm sure the only way to get detected is to stand in their direct line of sight, and even then it takes a few seconds for them to notice you. It's also apparent that you are playing as a perfectly weightless man, because you cannot hear your footsteps at all - I'm serious, they are completely silent. Because of this, you can sprint up behing an enemy and stab him with no difficulty at all.

Definitely one of my less enjoyed shooters, but at least the sniping is a bit (and I do mean a VERY SMALL BIT) more realistic than Call of Duty.

The original Sniper: Ghost Warrior game was terrible. You can argue that all you want but having played it myself and not gotten a refund, I won't listen. The shooting mechanics offer some variety on the higher difficulty settings but overall the lack of challenging shots leaves a lot to be desired. The positioning aspect of the game amounts to walking along a predetermined path to painfully obvious hides. You take out a few waves of enemies with your high powered rifle. You move on to the next level.

While this is no-punches-pulled for what the game advertises, I find it hard to justify the price when a much more competent competitor lets you enjoy shooting Hitler between the legs. If you want a ballistics simulation get either Sniper Elite v2 or Arma 3.

If you want that Pripyat level of Call of Duty for an entire game, look no further.

I did not check out the multiplayer and the hours I put into this games is for 1 playthrough on hard getting every single player achievement.  And some hours of Alt-Tab to do something else.

***REVIEW***

If you either enjoyed the first Sniper: Ghost Warrior or wanted a modern sniping game, this is a game worth checking out.  Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2 improved on the original in every way.

+ Took away the horrible close encounter and turret sections that was in the original.
+ More long range sniping section of 750+ meters.
+ Improved graphics and more varied locations.
+ More stealth sections and a stealth melee kill that was missing from the original.

- Couple of infrequent bugs, such as game freezing and loss of audio that were resolved by restarting the game.
Though I was playing on a laptop with an intel integrated graphic card, so that could had been the cause.
- Pistol was overpowered, I don't remember ever killing a guy with more than one shot of it while on hard.  This made a couple of the stealth sections trival.

All in all, this game satisfy my want of a sniping game and considering that I got this game in a bundle, I can't complain with how much I paid for it.

I crouch with the dark and griity floor, my heartbeat goes into the triple digits, I lock and load my sniper rifle, I take aim, steady my breathing, and pull the trigger.

As I was playing Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2 I eager to try out a new form of gameplay. As a Gamer I never had a chance to try out how to become a sniper so this game was definitely a can opener to what awaits me.

Needless to say I was far from dissapointed.

Yes, the campaign was short, however the play-through was thrilling and tension breaking.

Trying to complete mission parameters wilthout letting the enemy know of your position and being as stealthy as possible will test your patience and skill with the gun itself.

Many times I wander WHY THE HELL DID I JUST GO RAMBO!??

Only to realize duh, your supposed to wait, then strike when the time is right.

I would ill advise the impatient, guns-blazing, hero maniacs out there because YOU WILL GET SHOT DOWN. it only takes several hits to even take you down few if hit in vital areas.

But, I digress, those out there that have the patience of iron will I challenge your stealth and patience and most of all determination to blaze through this game without healing once, or being detected, step it up a notch by cranking it up to it's max difficulty and you've got a hard-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• game that will make your eyes squint on your monitor.

Multiplayer is tediuous, many times your enemies and your teammates will camp and search for your enemy. Or the enemy will get tired of waiting and go through enemy lines Rambo style with a pistol.

Eh, To be honest, did teach a perspective for noobie snipers of just how hard a sniper's job really is, a small glimpse, but a worthy immersion into this unforgiving world where one bullet is all it takes to kill a soul.

Hesitate and you will fail, steady yourself or else all will be for naught, be aware of your surroundings, for you never know what lurks in the dark, and hopefully you'll live another day without a bullet through your head yesterday.

Don't jump the gun so soon...

so finally, 3 years after its release i get around to playing this game, overall it's a good stealth shooter, still in two minds on whether or not it's better than the first though, but i just got done with its campaign in just over 8 hours so figured i'd do a review

pros: beautiful scenery, nice weapon models (minus the handgun, not sure what it was but something about it rubbed me the wrong way) fairly challenging even on medium, missions aren't really repetive

cons: AI is a bit rubbish (example, my spotter told me it was time to run past a spotlight, told me exactly as the spotlight came back on to us as he ran right through it) some shots don't always register as hits which in turn gets you spotted, if you are spotted it gets a bit ridiculous as you seem to have about as much protection as a wet paper bag would give you, a bit on the short side, limited weapons options.


conclusion: Sniper ghost warrior 2 is a good, challenging and fun game, despite its 'issues' i will certainly be playing through this again on a harder difficulty and will gladly recommend it to others, however, i can't recommend people buy it at full price, either get it on sale or check external sites, i picked up the trilogy collection on humblebundle for less than ¬£4

Basically a decent arcade shooter with a strong console feel to it.

Visually, it's quite decent, the audio is fairly immersive although the weapon sounds are so-so.
The missions are extremely linear but well designed, alternating stealth and action.

Compared to the big" titles of the same genre like COD
date: the difference mostly shows in the way the player character is managed. Here you never feel like you have a choice. It's basically a number of different levels to beat as they were designed to be beaten. Stray from the path and you'll get killed. Games with a larger budget like COD manage to hide this fact much more effectively.\n\nSupposedly you can shoot enemies behind cover but in practice you can't (most military bullets will pass through wood
recommended: not in this game). Except for glass.\n\nAll in all a decent entry in a fairly crowded genre."

Now, if you ever played the first Sniper Ghost Warrior, you wouldn't enjoy this at all.
A lot has changed from game to game, some for better but in my mind for worse.
I'll make a small pros+cons list for you

Pros of Sniper Ghost Warrior 2 vs 1
-Beautiful graphics, the game now uses Cryengine over whatever they used before
-smooth movement through the world
-bullent drop and wind haven't really changed, not much else to say
-much more story based, certainly more 'attatchable' than the first
-checkpoints are plently, but only at key points to not make the game too tedious (or so they tried)
-some moments you can really connect with your main character (though the story is so short it's shortlived)
(I'll be honest, I'm really struggling to find more pros, and I'm trying damn hard)

Cons of ''
-With the use of cryengine, everything starts to feel a little plastic and unrealistic
-The story mode is almost completely linear, lot of handholding involved (a lot!)
-The game feels completely unreal as all parts of the story are revolved around the player doing something before hand (for better clerification, you can stand still for 3 days and nothing will happen. walk to this spot and suddenly boat, helicopter, jeep, etc.)
-Story is short and pretty easy to get through
-With being more linear, the game is much less focussed on stealth rather than getting through to objectives
-There are bugs aplenty
-enemies can sometimes see through trees that you can't (shrubs have the vision block, not trees, so enemies see through them like glass)
-whenever you're sneakin' about and you suddenly notice a badly placed object or shrud (usually floating a foot or two above the ground) it ruins the moment
-This is the last con I'll be adding, and it's the one I hate most. EVERYTHING is sequenced. As said before with the 'three days standing still example', it goes further than just enemies spawning. it also includes enemies despawning (three twice when they were in straight eye site in only the first mission!), having the little arrow above enimies and friends and watching them dissapear as soon as they're out of sight is frustration for a game supposedly desinged around realism, and last of the pile, the game hand holds so much that you sometimes have to wait to be told to shoot someone. that sounds normal though, let me tell you what I'm refering too.
mission 2, on your way to the observertory, you have to sneak around the left of a building after having shot a sentry above the building. Shoot the sentry too soon and you get spotted, you actually have to wait for your comms to TELL you to shoot him and only then will he not alert the guards. And this happens all the time. Shoot someone before you're told and you get spotted. none of the characters even have to change position from be fore to after you're told to shoot.

This is becoming a lot to read through so I'm going to stop on this note.
In my mind, the first Sniper Ghost Warrior was clunky, hard to manage through and overall hard to play. But it gave you a SO much better experience of what it means to be a sniper. Not this Ghost Warrior 2 game. It's smoother and more plastic, much less realistic and doesn't mamange to beat the original.

This is a solid game that improves on the original.

The graphics are impressive, however, there are still a few bugs:
1) if I alt-tab out, the screen flickers between sepia and normal until I quit the game
2) the intro for each mission starts out fine but bugs out after 15-20 seconds... the audio stops and the graphics pause, preventing you from hearing the rest of the briefing and forcing you to wait up to 30 seconds before pressing enter to begin
3) occassionally (4 times so far) the game will crash for no apparent reason

These don't stop it being a very enjoyable game. The same sniper tactics are there from the first game and the story, while moderately short, is fairly engaging with a decent array of characters and plot twists.

Overall, a game that I'd recommend to those interested in stepping off the beating track from the regular FPS rinse and repeat cycle.

The game cost me only about $4 when it was on sale, so I have to say I am actually pretty happy with the game.  The game play is pretty smooth, and seems to have most elements that most modern sniper games do: prone/crouch/stand, night vision, optical zoom scopes, stealth kills, controlled breathing, etc.  I've only played a little of it, but plan to play more in the future. If you like sniper/infiltration games, you may enjoy this as part of your collection.
